txt: It is sometimes worth making it more difficult to travel to make certain places safer and more attractive, such as schools and town centers
Central government should fund the infrastructure build, this is an unprecedented emergency that will eventually effect everyone.
Bicycle tourism has supported the economies of many small towns. The worst thing we could do is impose levies that discourage this.
Trucks aren't on the roads to wreck them or the planet. They are on the road because people ask them to move their goods.
Public transportation should be entirely state-funded and free for everyone.
Is there a risk that huge investment in EV may be followed by a completely different tech and huge revenue wastage?
The system needs to make investment in rail services easier and cheaper to support mode shift and more inter-regional travel by rail
Public sector should provide scootering and bike hire. The private provision of these makes them too expensive compared with driving
SUVs and Utes should pay considerably higher ACC levies for the risk they pose to regular road users and pedestrians.
Tolling all new roads or motorways is going to be too harsh a financial burden on less well-off families/ communities.
If those who benefit from a new or additional transport option can be identified, they should contribute to the costs.
Regional rail travel doesn't need to be directly profitable, because the benefits will be recouped in the wider economy and local tourism
There is nothing stopping private enterprise from providing such services as it is. They don’t / won’t, without govt subsidy.
The ETS should be the main driver of mode shift. Cut the cap and let the price rise big time. Use the carbon dividend for equity
parking and congestions charges must consider impact on low income households
All people benefit from the transport system. Therefore, general taxation should at least partially fund it.
Retaining our privacy is an important value. Even if we have user pays systems they shouldn't track our movements.
Penalties for drivers who injure or kill vulnerable people (ie pedestrians, cyclists) need to be reformed to ensure proper deterrence
The future of accessibility and transport infra is not more of what we have now.
Freight requirements are fixed. Slowing vehicles down will mean more vehicles are required to move the same amount of freight.
PPP's a wildly expensive due to the required profit margin. And funders ensure they socialise the risk of losses and privatise the profits.
Travel is the outcome of the spatial land use distribution. All transport & land use planning departments to be integrated & funded together
Public investment in punblic transport will reduce costs to households by reducing need to have several cars each
The transport revenue system should not make transport unaffordable for poorer people or people living in rural and provincial areas
active travel will not increase substantially  unless we build a network of protected cycleways in every city, and on the open road
Scrap projects aimed to reduce congestion - reuse funds for maintenance of current assets, PT improvements & active travel projects.
There should be more speed, red-light and phone usage cameras to increase safety and generate revenue from unsafe road users.
The public health costs of motorized transport (pollution, injury, sedentary lifestyle) should be a factor in levies.
The only fair way to pay for roads is 100% petrol tax and road user charges
Private sector involvement in revenue raising should be as agents of the state and road users, not as owners or concessionaires
Congestion charges are the only way to achieve objectives of reducing car usage in cities
funds ? taxes I think you mean
The FED & RUC incentivises Waka Kotahi to provide more roads for more cars, because these funds go directly into their coffers (the NLTF).
Ratepayers should not be paying for road damage caused by heavy transport
Public sector subsidy for scooters or bike hires makes sense, but not full provision
Long term strategic decision making is too vulnerable to shifts in election cycles leading to lost opportunity, investment and cost creep.
It's better for all of us if everyone can get where they want to.
Congestion charging should be implemented in the main urban centres
Allow the private sector to collect revenue using tolls and other innovative technologies (e.g, GPS technologies)
The Auckland motorway system ruins inner city Auckland. Similarly to international cities it should be dug up, and replaced with PT.
Changes should be based on empirical evidence and fact, not on popular opinion.
Direct road pricing - time,location,vehicle No ratepayer & developer transport contributions subsidy, no taxpayer funding
Hypothecation of fuel taxes and RUC is wrong. Taxes should be raised from sources with lowest impact, spent on investment with most benefit.
Pedestrians' and cyclists' road use should be paid for through rates.
Not at this stage - investment in safety, comfort and education on cycling to increase usage, instead of $ to cyclists.
Funding of transport should be scaled to public benefit - i.e. trains & busses receive maximum funding, private cars pay all externalities
Waka Kotahi/the NLTF should never have to take on debt to fund maintenance or operations; it should be reserved for new high value projects
The resource costs of electrification must be calculated and stated - the excavation and use of finite precious metals is unsustainable
The Public Finance Act should be re-written to remove unnecessary funding restriction that has starved transport investment since the 80s.
The current levels of funding support operation of the current network but do not provide for needed investment.
Update commercial tax rates and fringe benefit taxes to favour a shift towards cleaner transport modes and vehicles
because the risk of crashing a car relates to how much is used, the ACC levy should be charged only on a per-km basis, not part of rego fees
transport fines should scale with wealth, so they're still an effective punishment for the wealthy, and should be used to fund transport.
Until we get significantly better long distance & freight transport, mode shift is too inefficient.
councils should be allowed to charge rates on state highways that are in their territory
Competition between providers is good if it improves a service but not if this is to the detriment of unprofitable but necessary routes
All vehicles including cycles and scooters should be electronically monitored for RUC and congestion charges
Yes we absolutely need to enable urban density.  It is the only thing that will genuinely shift the dial on transport emissions
Charge all vehicles that use the roading system Road User Charges, including electric vehicles and bikes
Road user charges should reflect the damage that large vehicles do to the roads, with heavier vehicles paying a proportionate share.
The first priority for the fuel tax and road user charges paid by drivers and motorcyclists should be for looking after the roads.
Commercial vehicles should be charged more than private vehicles
And e-scooters
The rich benefit most. Tax the rich.
Developer contributions for transport should not be paid by developers but by road users
Reducing disadvantage requires PT services and cycling routes that are travel time competitive with driving
The transport system should also promote well-being, fairness and equity
Involving private entities in public transport will prioritize a profitable system at a cost to convenience/safety/accessibility/cheapness.
Road users to pay full retrospective costs to mitigate existing road noise, community severance, soil & water pollution + fund future costs
Parking and congestion charges are inappropriate mechanisms to reduce car use as they have negative impact on low income households.
Rural areas face big challenges from long distances, old roads, high speeds and poor safety
Public transport, walking and cycling reduces spend in areas like traffic accidents and healthcare. That must be considered in funding it.
We need to replace FED tax with user pay system, with rates based on emissions/km.
No new motorways in the future - mass transport will occur on narrower corridors in shared vehicles - e.g. buses, trains
Bring back the fuel tax and make public transport free. Force people to shift modes
When fuel excise taxes resume, they should be postponed in areas where people have inadequate public transport alternatives.
Transport responses related to climate change need to be funding from the fuel type causing the polution.
Agency funding (local & national) should be linked to their performance delivering the infra needed for low-emission, safe transport.
The NTLF should invest its funds more equitably and take a significant shift away from roading projects
Coastal shipping needs to play much bigger role in the future & could reduce the operation and capital costs of the land transport system
Every airport should be connected to town by an adequate bus service.
Perspective: transport funding has excessively subsidised fossil-fuel powered road vehicles over other modes for decades.
ETS revenue should pay for lower emission transport
Congestion charges should be implemented in cities to discourage use of private cars in city centres with good public transport
Funding priorities need to shift from a focus on roads and private vehicles to more environmentally sustainable forms of transport
Costs should be weighted towards heavy vehicles. They are less safe and cause more damage to roads.
Where road space is limited we should reallocate it to public transport, cycling and walking as they all have much higher capacity than cars
The transport infra we most need to fund is that which we have starved of meaningful funding over recent decades: walk,cycle, rail, bus.
If new transport projects mean property values increase, those who benefit should contribute funds to that project
Government funding public infrastructure (rail network, cycleways) is preferable to private/commercial entities.
Vehicles most dangerous to cyclists (tall trucks, utes) should fund cycle lanes via targeted levies
Agree
Fuel Excise Duty should be abandoned and all motor vehicles pay Road User Charges in direct proportion to the amount of road damage they do.
All new motorways must be tolled in future. This should be a standard policy position.
Trucks pay too much relative to cars now that so much funding goes to public transport and rail
We should design our transport system to be accessible to everyone, all the time Not just able bodied people travelling at peak times
Present system incentivises WK to motor vehicle use as this means more income to the NLTF, yet we need disincentivise driving for climate.
Public transport should be free until road and air transport bear all their long and short term financial, social and environmental costs.
Construction of new roads or upgrades should be looked upon more favourably if they enable PT (e.g. priority bus lanes) or active transport
Public transport should be an integrated system that includes buses, trains, e-scooters, bikes and other forms of micromobility
Speed camera fines should go back into road safety
Induced demand means that investment in infrastructure that support cars will never meet demand, because it causes more people to drive.
New roads should be funded from financial contribution from developers or new housing from the contributing districts.
Waka Kotahi (NZTA) should be allowed to borrow more against its own assets to pay for roading maintenance and upgrades
Use innovative mechanisms such as congestion charges and pollution pricing to encourage people out of cars and into other forms of environmentally sustainable transport
street upgrades, seawalls and placemaking shouldn't be funded completely from the cycleways budget just because they include a cycleway
we should charge developers less if they build homes or businesses that increase demand for transit, walking & cycling, but not for driving
Too many questions. Got bored. NOT ONE ON CLIMATE CRISIS!!!
More & higher tax + more govt funding needed to help transform trans infra. BUT disproportionate impact on lower income must be mitigated.
Invest in walking, cycling, and public transport infrastructure. Fewer cars on the road will result in reduced road maintenance costs.
The government should subside purchase of e-bikes to get people out of their cars
Annual vehicle fixed licence fees should cover the fixed costs of providing roads.
Replace FED with an expanded RUC that applies to all vehicles with a variable charge for time and location of travel and emissions
Public transport is a win-win: people don't have to invest so much in their cars, frees up streets and roads for commercial traffic
Motor vehicles are the key risk to pedestrians and cyclists, so motor vehicle drivers should pay for this sort of safety improvement
Public transport should be free for all.
It's much more important that government funds the right projects and gets value for money, than how it raises revenue.
Road user charges should be based on the level of 'cost' a vehicle type/user has - road maintenance, health/pollution, emissions, energy
This UI is terrible
There needs to be a major shift in funding priorities. Less money for new roads, more money for alternatives modes (bikes, buses, rail)
Heavy transport should pay considerably more than at present to fund the road degradation they cause
It's more important that public transport is good than that it's cheap. Increased funding should mean more services before lower fares.
Speed cameras should become more prominent and fines more significant to both gather revenue and reduce speeds.
Gear funding to optimise zero carbon transport in 25 years with dramatically less private transport and funding from central government.
A first class roading system is needed, EVEN if we discourage private car use - buses, cyclists, etc all need good roading
Drastic changes are required to meet the demands of our emissions reduction plans
Compulsory third party insurance and emissions standards should also be introduced.
Is there a risk that decisions regarding transport will be driven by politicians in Wellington and Auckland to the detriment of all others?
Transport is one system. It's okay to use revenue from road users to pay for rail, or from users of one road to pay for another.
Current funding discussions do not seem to take into account that alternative fuels are going to become available.
The best way to reduce carbon emissions from transport is to properly implement the ETS.  Do this fast so that carbon is fully priced
Congestion charging buys time for, pushes uptake of lasting solutions - public transport, active mode infrastructure, livable cities
Our transport revenue system should make it as cheap as possible to drive wherever people want
electric cars and trucks should not be exempt from paying their fair share to maintain the transport network
Pedestrians need to be accommodated through protection from sun, from construction works, and from traffic noise.
Infrastructure funding has to be about getting people and goods to destinations when needed, not merely whenever. Late buses = no buses.
Funding local roads through Council rates drives regional inequality, as poorer areas lack the needed funds for transport improvements.
road user charges should be based on the weight and space the vehicle takes up. Space efficiency benefits us all.
Invest in new technology to make walking the best option - smart crossings, better footpath surfaces, hill escalators (like Hong Kong)
ACC should contribute to the costs of improving road safety
Pedestrians should be educated to be careful near roads. It is not up to road users to fund safety features for people.
Public transport must be funded by the region it services. It's unfair for Southland/Northland to pay for Aucklands public transport.
The land transport funding system should encourage more freight to move by rail to reduce the need to repair and expand our road network
The transport system should enable goods and people to move efficiently and safely
use innovative mechanisms such as congestion charges and pollution pricing to encourage people to make smart transport choices
a well functioning well funded transport system (all modes) supports all sectors of society
Distinguish cost recovery revenue tools (FED, RUC, flat tolls) from behaviour change tools (variable tolls, road pricing): transparency
The funding system should support the Emissions Reduction Plan to reduce total kilometres travelled by the light fleet by 20% by 2035
Speed limits in suburban non-arterials and suburban town centres should be reduced to a maximum of 30kph.
Funding for modal options from RUC should be clear so people can see the link.
Funding for transport in urban centres should be different than for Regional and rural NZ
We need to put more effort into efficient spending - not just increasing the money available
Buses should be made available especially for people within retirement homes, as they lack access to public transport
Safety projects must be justified by comparison with actual safety generated to claw back billions spent per year without real safety gain.
Trucks deliver necessary goods and services. Transport companies should not be penalised for providing a service everyone requires.
Redirect the transport budget to develop our active and public transport infrastructure.
Transport is a natural monopoly, and as such private partnerships are an inappropriate funding mechanism
the default urban speed limit should be 30 kph, and enforced by speed cameras.
Public Transport should be free. It is a public service, and is a benefit to all, whether you use it or not. So it should be paid for by all
Digital RUC with variable pricing is essential. Pricing of RUC should cost less for off peak and more for peak travel periods.
Commercial vehicles should pay more, as they financially benefit from the transport network.
Stop building motorways unless there is a clear, obvious benefit to a motorway over a rail line (particularly as rail is often cheaper/km)
The Government should pay for all public transport necessities. Public transport for free. Internet, an office, and food inside transports.
perverse incentives
Developers should not make contributions towards the roading costs
Tolling is a blunt tool for all new motorways, ideally we want people to use the new safer route. Broader pricing tools target outcomes.
the transport revenue system should give councils more tools to raise their own revenue from transport in their region
Rural regions cannot afford to maintain rural roads.   More funding from central government would help.
There needs to be an effective system to deter bad behaviour. Fines are too low because they haven't been increased with incomes.
New land transport investment decisions should be unbiased and funding sources must not favour expanding road building.
FED and RUC should contribute to all modes as it is a system
There should be limits on vehicle size to discourage large SUV use in urban areas and pricing can help with this
With the need to meet a 20% reduction in VKT by 2035 vs 2035 baseline the current NLTP & project funding should be fully reviewed
We need to cater to, and centrally fund, the transport options available to our most vulnerable: public transport, walking, cycling
We should provide the transport that all people need, which is not the same as the transport that the vocal people want.
Wellington is the obvious city to implement a congestion charging scheme as it has good PT.  It can pave the way for other urban centres.
The problem is RUC overheads are too high for light fleet etc
Local government funding needs to be significantly increased to make up for historic funding deficits.
There are wider benefits to a functioning transport system beyond users. Govt should spend more of the national tax take on transport.
Public transport should run all day, every day, regardless of how many people use it.
If all road users contributed the individual cost could be kept low.
It is very rare to be able to achieve perfect or even mildly imperfect competition.  Other mechanisms may be better to achieve best outcomes
Remove restriction on local authorities owning and operating public transport - removing the need for a profit for private sector owners
The current contracting model for the delivery of road maintenance activities on state highways is not achieving the right outcomes
Public transport & emergency vehicles should be exempt from (or pay greatly reduced) RUCs with private users subsidising any shortfall.
VKT reduction measures should apply to Tier1&2 cities only. Recognising this is key for drafting up policies, can't ignore system inherited
We need to increase taxes on road usages. That involve cars such as fuel taxes, parking, etc. to fund public transport improvement
Vehicle users should pay a levy towards mitigating pollution of water & soil ecological systems
Fuel excise duty is a ridiculous way to fund transport. Doesn't reflect the true cost or external impacts of how people travel.
Emissions reduction initiatives should be paid for by the Government, not road users
The challenge is to get the right mix of free-market and public sector interventions, because getting it wrong results in failures like PTOM
The transport system should be self-funded by its users and others who benefit.
Bikes don't cause road damage (as so light) so shouldn't pay RUC
Taxpayers not to fund land transport unless there is a NZ social equity cost to mitigate, e.g access to fast frequent PT for transit captive
We should not link safety enforcement with revenue raising as it creates perverse incentives to improve revenue certainty
Rail (all kinds) should receive the largest portion of funding across the transport sector
Parking levies are an effective way to raise revenue and change travel behaviour.
Local authorities should be able to raise revenue with parking charges, congestion charging and enforcement, to invest it in transport.
Stop funding transport with people's lives. 30kmh on all urban surface streets, >30kmh only on those with vision zero design incl junctions
The public consultation process is broken and creates expensive, compromised projects that aim to please everyone but actually please no one
Fines for car drivers abusing cycling infrastructure (like parking in bike lanes) should go entirely to cycling infrastructure.
Rather than pricing people out of some transport, the focus should be on providing good options to make the change attractive
Separated bike lanes should be standard around every school.
When devising planning rules, we must not get confused between urban amenity & building design.  Ugly buildings can still have good amenity.
Vehicle registration charges should be based on vehicle mass and emissions.
Public Transport, Walking and Cycling are not viable options in most of regional and rural NZ.
Electric vehicle subsidies are promoting a technology that is going to overtake the countries ability to provide he power to sustain them.
To what purpose? Land transport is integrated across the nation. Private sector have vested interests that may not deliver on integration
given the very high costs of recent motorway projects, including for remedial maintenance, all new motorway projects should be tolled.
The full costs, including a degraded envirornment and poorer health, of driving should be reflected in the financial cost.
E-bikes are more important to subsidise and incentivise than electric cars
This depends on how one qualifies 'paying' - the fiscal cost of private may be cheaper; the intangible costs of private can be immense.
good theory - if you can design a equitable and workable mechanism
Light road users should only contribute to the costs of maintenance of roads if their infrastructure gets the same level of investment
We should reprioritise how we design, fund, and use transport infrastructure: pedestrians first, then bicycles, EV mobility, etc
Initiatives to improve well being / the climate cannot be implemented without first having meaningful solutions to essential services.
Funding should incentivise low carbon modes (walking, cycling, public transport) and disincentivise carbon-intensive modes (motor vehicles)
The people who've made the most money using the current network should pay more to remedy its problems for future generations.
Large malls and other big shopping destinations should be designed around public transport, not roads and cheap land.
We need to shift to collective modes run without fossil fuels. These are collective costs so rates and taxes are the way to pay for them
For a complex system the state must subsidise desirable outcomes but allow competitive engagement.
we should focus transport capital investment to bring up to standard places without functioning public transport and micromobility networks
New Zealand needs a public health messaging campaign to broadly communicate and educate the precarious costs of unfettered car dependency.
NZ has an ok RUC system, we just need to add petrol and electric vehicles and allow users to chose fixed or variable pricing. FED is dead.
Shifting the cost burden onto the commercial fleet, will result in increased cost of delivered goods and services increasing household costs
Electric Vehicles need to pay their share and have road user charges
The use of market mechanisms to raise revenue for the transport system would promote the principles of efficiency, fairness, property rights
Do not overinvest in EV yet, there will be new technologies to come along that could be better.
Charging RUC is the only fair systems. Currently, recreational (non road use) petrol vehicles are disadvantaged. (Boats; aircraft etc)
gimmeee subsideesssss
Vehicles should be emissions tested as part of WOF / COF, as other countries do. Vehicles with poor test results should pay penalty charges.
A levy on carparks is a fair way to encourage mode shift and raise transport revenue from those that create transport demand.
Pedestrians' rights have been heavily eroded over the years, and need to be respected and restored.
The NLTF should be increased to support the whole transport system, including rail
Bikes should be exempt from fringe benefit tax (currently 64%) so employers are motivated to provide bikes & encourage bike-to-work schemes
Public transport should be free for everybody and funded by taxpayers.
Transport funding decisions should always improve the level of service for people on foot or cycle.
RUCs and council funding should go into a common pot of funds for all transport modes. No more than 50% of it should be spent on roads.
I think people in cars become anti social because they are unaware of the people who won't or can't use cars.
we should tax things that create harms, and invest in things that create benefits - including costs and harms that go beyond just transport.
Public/private partnerships usually result in privatising profits and socialising losses.
Congestion charging should be used on the vehicles that contribute most to congestion
the transport revenue system should encourage people not to use light trucks (utes) as passenger cars
Diesel vehicles damage health in cities and road pricing mechanisms in built up areas should reflect these costs.
Introduce fuel rationing to incentivise alternative travel modes and to meet our emissions reductions targets.
A well designed land tax will help incentivise better land use and direct investment away from car dependent sprawl.
Road users funding from Fuel Excise Duty and RUC should be solely used to for the maintenance, minor capital works, and safety improvements
To eliminate congestion this is the crucial thing:   "We have to make car commuting not the most attractive option for most people".
Preserving privacy is important so when we build systems to monitor transport use we should'nt track individual users
All urban schools should have separated (from the road) bike paths for at least 1km in the two main routes  leading to them.
For every dollar invested on roads, there should be at least that amount spent on bike paths and rail, ideally more
Dedicated bus lanes should required on every road or motorway with more than 1 lane in each direction.
Use variable road pricing to encourage people to shift journey times
Lots of the costs of transport are indirect - emissions, effects on neighbouring homes - we need to make policy decisions not use the market
too much parking and lack of protected cycleways is holding back active travel
The best way of reducing disadvantage is through the welfare system, for example by providing higher levels of subsidy for transport for lower income people
The transport funding system needs to move to a beneficiary pays system, not a simple user pays system. Beneficiaries are wider than users.
Disadvantaged groups must be given opportunities to participate in decision-making about future transport systems and how they will be funded
We need to replace FED tax with user pay system based on KMs travelled, with rates based on emissions/km & facility type used. GPS vehicles.
Road funding should go into Avoiding the need to travel, Shifting people to low emission/congestion modes and Improving vehicle emissions
For some people cars are the only option. They should not be disadvantaged by transport systems that are not accessible
Some | All | None ?
road user charges should consider peoples access to appropriate public transport services
If this were to happen, it could motivate motorists to oppose safety improvements to keep their costs down...
If we don't fund low-emission rural transport our land will stop being as productive due to climate change.
Fund a rail service to the northwest of Auckland Waitakere-Kumeu/Huapai-Waimauku-Helensville ahead of regional passenger rail. Needed now.
Reallocate our existing road space rather than extend the roading network to support mode shift.
Cycleways, bus lanes and pedestrian crossings are only required due to the presence of motorists,  therefore motorists should pay for them.
Road user changes should be in proportion to amount of damage done to roads (e.g. heavy trucks pay more, others less)
The cost of 1 fatality on our roads is averaged at $5.8mil. Focus on saving lives and you will save funds benefiting the social network.
Funding more than just roads is critical to long-term economic success for NZ.
New roads should be funded from financial contribution from developers
It's better to pay a fair share for transport now rather than leave more debt for future generations.
Pay people to, and have tax relief for employers to support people walking and using public transport
Conditions in public transport should not divide a life "before" and "after" but permit one to work not only to wait and sleep. Peace, relax
Vehicle insurance should be mandatory and a levy should be added to premiums which covers the negative health costs of transport.
Road user charges should also be based on a holistic assessment of the overall societal costs that each mode of transport has.
Safety should be prioritised over efficiency in all cases (ie efficiency improvements should only be done if they can be done safely)
Make much greater use of public/private partnerships to inject private sector money and expertise into the transport system
Privatisation swaps wages for bureaucratic processes to ensure projects meet social needs, for shortcuts to ensure profits for private gains
Buses should be free for users, funded by rate payers
we should focus our transport capital investment on places that are zoned to grow substantially in population or employment in future
Bike share is public transport too! It should be subsidised for first/ last leg trips to public transport
Treasury needs to fund NZTA's staff costs directly. It is currently conflicted in the way it funds itself from the NLTF
The best way of reducing disadvantage is to redistribute wealth and income more equally, but transport subsidies are helpful.
Trains should be the primary method of travel between centres, and high speed services should replace air travel, for safety and emissions
This would require registration of bikes which is extremely burdensome and will reduce cycling significantly.
Private transportation is often for an employer's benefit, so employers should bear that part of the cost.
All (new import) vehicles should be subject to ongoing emissions levies as part of their registration. Exclude existing cars for equity
Our funding system should enable the design of transport systems that are accessible to everyone, all the time. Not just able bodied people travelling at peak times
Increase urban density to make public transport and active forms (walking and cycling) of transport more affordable and attractive
Equity is important but not all transport policies need to be equitable, as long as other govt policies outside transport make up for it
If we are serious about an efficient and sustainable transport system we should charge the full costs to each mode, including injury and co2
the answer to raising revenue for the future transport system is not obvious.Conflicts with modes fuelled by ICE may not be resolved by EVs.
Vehicle drivers are massively subsidised. Only through them paying closer to full costs will we reduce VKT, emissions & improve road safety
I reackon that we should introduce a wealth tax, to make the ultra-rich pay their fair share & fund public/active transport.
why just e-bikes? all environmentally friendly means of transport should be considered equally, including manual bikes
The government shouldn't provide storage for private cars on street for free. Drivers who park should pay for parking, not ratepayers.
Follow the example of other countries that pay people per km cycled to compensate them for the benefits cycling creates for all in better health and reduced cars
Road User Charges should include even more of the external costs like pollution
The Treaty of Waitangi should be considered in all new roading
Routes aren't the solution; it's connectivity that matters. Routes that don't interconnect are wasteful.
our transport system should enhance the places it goes through, and the places it goes to, not undermine them
Roads are for more than just vehicles.
private sector finance initiatives (e.g. PPPs) are a valuable way of bridging our infrastructure deficit and spreading cost to future users
Rural communities are more challenging to mode shift. Infrastructure and services are more costly and there are fewer users to fund it all.
The best transport policy is a housing policy. Dense housing near the places where people work makes public and active transport viable
Mode cost allocation seems economically rational but practically infeasible. True cost allocation requires value judgments
Private vehicles under a certain weight (~200kgs not incl. passengers) should be exempt from all forms of RUC.
GPS road user charging data should be able to be used for enforcement, eg for speeding
We should be rapidly building separated cycle ways, on all main routes to keep everyone safe but at much lower costs.
Emergency road maintenance work should be funded from climate change budget
There is a need  for more investment that supports modal shift
All road users including cycles and micro-mobility modes should share the costs of maintaining and building roads
cycleways built on seawalls needed to protect roads from seal evel rise should be paid for out of the road budget, not the cycling budget
If I travel only because my boss makes me go to the office for work I could have done at home, that's my employer who benefits, not me.
Petrol taxes should pay for not just the costs of roads, but also their wider negative impacts on society, like air pollution and noise
Overall I can see a much reduced level of investment in major new roads but some will still be needed to make the system operate efficiently
Getting cars off the road benefits those who do need to drive. So funding for other transport should draw on car-related revenue streams.
Rail should be funded outside of the NLTF - not by trucks
Shipping and rail should not be funded by REGO or RUC.
Fuel Excise & Road User charges need supplementing.
transport investment should be focused on reducing the harm the transport system causes, not on making transport easier
There are too many cars in NZ. Higher levies, higher gas taxes / RUC charges would improve life for both car drivers and PT users.
Ratepayers should not fund transport.  They are not direct system users.  Actual road users should fund the transport system
Roads are for all users who should pay their proportinate share
Tax incentives that encourage people to buy utes instead of cars should be completely abolished.
transport funding decisions should be mode agnostic and based on moving the most people or freight for least cost/impact
We need to stop investing so much in to roads and get more people moving on trains and light rail.
The government should compensate a loss in property value if a transport project causes a decrease
Road revenue should come from RUC for all, despite fuel type; fuel taxes should fund climate change adaptation, rates set to push change
Needed: a more imaginative approach to public transport e.g.  piloting Ubers / taxis in a specific suburb, with $ modelling on benefits
Funding through rates and FAR is more manageable for large councils, joint funding arrangements across councils to spread costs equitably
land use development should support people's ability to reduce travel demands
Rail should be the primary area of new investment, as there are more than enough motorways in the country and almost no rail outside AKL+WGT
We need ferries and rail.
We need more cycling infrastructure in the country. You're not stuck in traffic, you are the traffic. More ebikes and less queues.
Intercity bus and rail services should focus on everyday travel for New Zealanders, not luxury travel for tourists.
If local govt was funded properly they wouldnt have to be.
The new transport funding system should have a very clear separation of maintenance costs (operational) vs capital costs.
FED and RUC should contribute to all modes as it is s system
Active transport requires capital investment but causes little need for maintenance. Therefore there is no need to charge a ruc equivalent.
Before full road pricing introduce congestion tolling to substantially reduce the need 4 very expensive road capacity improvement projects.
Feight subsidies in the road transport system should be removed to allow rail to compete. eg Rates currently subsidies freight transport

Stop wasting money on huge roading projects which only induce demand by making car travel more convenient.
A new funding mechanism for transport is needed ASAP. The current NLTF already cannot afford to maintain or improve the transport network.
More freight should be carried via rail to get heavy transport off the road network
Is this innovative; or run of the mill? I don't think we're innovating yet; except for a growth in values based/evocative messaging.
I can't believe we are still talking about congestion charging in 2022.  Just get on and do it, OK! It is the only way to achieve objectives
We need to move logistical transport off the roads and reduce the number of heavy trucks.
The income from congestion charging should not be collected by private entities - it should be fully reinvested in the transport network"
